column2: the Netherlands was invaded by Nazi Germany on 10 May 1940

column1: The Netherlands was placed under German occupation

column1: World War II occurred in four distinct phases in the European Netherlands:
September 1939 to May 1940: After the war broke out
column2: the Netherlands declared neutrality. The country was subsequently invaded and occupied.

column1: May 1940 to June 1941: An economic boom caused by orders from Germany
column2: combined with the "velvet glove" approach from Arthur Seyss-Inquart
column3: resulted in a comparatively mild occupation.

column1: June 1941 to June 1944: As the war intensified
column2: Germany demanded higher contributions from occupied territories
column3: resulting in a decline of living standards. Repression against the Jewish population intensified and thousands were deported to extermination camps. The "velvet glove" approach ended.

column1: June 1944 to May 1945: Conditions deteriorated further
column2: leading to starvation and lack of fuel. The German occupation authorities gradually lost control over the situation. Fanatical Nazis wanted to make a last stand and commit acts of destruction. Others tried to mitigate the situation.Most of the south of the country was liberated in the second half of 1944. The rest
column3: especially the west and north of the country still under occupation
column4: suffered from a famine at the end of 1944
column5: known as the "Hunger Winter". On 5 May 1945
column6: the whole country was finally liberated by the total surrender of all German forces.

column1: Dutch governments between 1929 and 1943 were dominated by Christian and center-right political parties. From 1933

column3: which had begun in 1929. The incumbent government of Hendrikus Colijn pursued a programme of extensive cuts to maintain the value of the Guilder
column4: resulting in workers' riots in Amsterdam and a naval mutiny between 1933 and 1934. Eventually

column13: both in number of members and numbers of voters.

column2: the Netherlands was invaded on the morning of 10 May 1940
column3: without a formal declaration of war

column1: The armed forces of the Netherlands
column2: with insufficient and outdated weapons and equipment
column3: were caught largely unprepared. Much of their weaponry had not changed since the First World War. In particular
column4: the Royal Netherlands Army did not have comparable armoured forces
column5: and could mount only a limited number of armoured cars and tankettes. The air force had only 140 aircraft
column6: mostly outdated biplanes. Sixty-five of the Dutch aircraft were destroyed on the first day of the campaign.The invading forces advanced rapidly but faced significant resistance. A Wehrmacht parachute assault on the first day
column7: aimed at capturing the Dutch government in The Hague and the key airfields at Ockenburg and Ypenburg
column8: was defeated by Dutch ground forces

column10: the German forces succeeded in crossing the Maas river in the Netherlands on the first day
column11: which allowed the Wehrmacht to outflank the nearby Belgian Fort Eben-Emael and force the Belgian army to withdraw from the German border.In the eastern Netherlands

column13: but their advance was slowed by the Dutch fortifications on the narrow Afsluitdijk Causeway linking the north-eastern and north-western parts of the Netherlands. The German forces advanced rapidly
column14: and by the fourth day were in control of most of the east of the country. They did not control the major cities in the west.

column2: while Utrecht has also been threatened with destruction. In order to spare the civil population and to prevent further bloodshed I feel myself justified in ordering all troops concerned to suspend operations ... By great superiority of the most modern means [the enemy] has succeeded in breaking our resistance. We have nothing wherewith to reproach ourselves in connection with this war. Your bearing and that of the forces was calm

column2: the military regime began to persecute the Jews of the Netherlands. In 1940

The Jewish Council ultimately served as an instrument for organising the identification and deportation of Jews more efficiently; the Jews on the council were told and convinced they were helping the Jews.In May 1942
column10: Jews were ordered to wear the Star of David badges. Around the same time the Catholic Church in the Netherlands publicly condemned the government's action in a letter read at all Sunday parish services. Thereafter

column19: inclusive both of Dutch Jews and the refugees ensnared by the German invasion of 1940
column21: 000 survived at war's end in 1945. The survival rate of 27% is much lower than in neighboring Belgium
column22: where 60% of Jews survived. It is also lower than in France
column23: where 75% survived.Historians have offered several hypotheses about why the survival rate was much lower in the Netherlands than in the other western European countries; including the possibility that the German occupiers in the Netherlands were particularly vigorous in comparison to other occupied countries. The Netherlands included religion in its national records
column24: which reduced the opportunity for Jews to mask their ethnic and religious identity. How much did the cooperation of the Dutch authorities and the Dutch people contribute? Did the absence of forests in the Netherlands deprive the Jews of hiding places? Marnix Croes and Peter Tammes have examined these hypotheses by looking at the variations in survival between the different regions of the Netherlands. They conclude that most of these hypotheses do not explain the data. They suggest that a more likely explanation was the varying "ferocity" with which the Germans and their Dutch collaborators hunted Jews in hiding in the different regions. In 2002

column2: which had established a narrow salient between Eindhoven and Nijmegen. In the east of North Brabant and in Limburg
column3: British and American forces in Operation Aintree managed to defeat the remaining German forces west of the Meuse between late September and early December 1944
column4: destroying the German bridgehead between the Meuse and the Peel marshes. During this offensive the only tank battle ever fought on Dutch soil took place at Overloon.

column2: the Allies also advanced into the province of Zeeland. At the start of October 1944
column3: the Germans still occupied Walcheren and dominated the Scheldt estuary and its approaches to the port of Antwerp. The crushing need for a large supply port forced the Battle of the Scheldt in which First Canadian Army fought on both sides of the estuary during the month to clear the waterways. Large battles were fought to clear the Breskens Pocket
column4: Woensdrecht and the Zuid-Beveland Peninsula of German forces
column5: primarily "stomach" units of the Wehrmacht as well as German paratroopers of Battle Group Chill. German units composed of convalescents and the medically unfit were named for their ailment; thus
column6: "stomach" units for soldiers with ulcers.

column2: resistance south of the Scheldt had collapsed
column3: and the Canadian 2nd Infantry Division
column4: British 52nd (Lowland) Division and 4th Special Service Brigade all made attacks on Walcheren Island. Strong German defenses made a landing very difficult
column5: and the Allies responded by bombing the dikes of Walcheren at Westkapelle
column6: Vlissingen and Veere to flood the island. Though the Allies had warned residents with pamphlets
column7: 180 inhabitants of Westkappelle died. The coastal guns on Walcheren were silenced in the opening days of November and the Scheldt battle declared over; no German forces remained intact along the 64 mi (103 km) path to Antwerp.

column1: Following the offensive on the Scheldt
column2: Operation Pheasant was launched in conjunction to liberate North Brabant. The offensive after some resistance liberated most of region; the cities of Tilburg
column3: s-Hertogenbosch
column4: Willemstad and Roosendaal were liberated by British forces. Bergen Op Zoom was taken by the Canadians and the Polish 1st Armoured Division led by General Maczek liberated the city of Breda without any civilian casualties on 29 October 1944. The operation as a whole also broke the German positions which had defended the region along its canals and rivers.

column1: The Dutch government had not wanted to use the old water line when the Germans had invaded in 1940. It was still possible to create an island out of the Holland region by destroying dikes and flooding the polders
column2: this island contained the main cities. The Dutch government had decided that  too many people would die to justify the flooding. However
column3: Hitler ordered that Fortress Holland (German: Festung Holland) be held at any price. Much of the northern Netherlands remained in German hands until the Rhine crossings in late March 1945.

column1: The winter of 1944–1945 was very harsh
column2: which led to "hunger journeys" and many cases of starvation (about 30
column3: 000 casualties)
column4: exhaustion
column5: cold and disease. This winter is known as the Hongerwinter (literally
column6: "hunger winter") or the Dutch famine of 1944. In response to a general railway strike ordered by the Dutch government-in-exile in expectation of a general German collapse near the end of 1944
column7: the Germans cut off all food and fuel shipments to the western provinces in which 4.5 million people lived. Severe malnutrition was common and 18
column8: 000 people starved to death. Relief came at the beginning of May 1945.

column1: After crossing the Rhine at Wesel and Rees
column2: Canadian
column3: British and Polish forces entered the Netherlands from the east
column4: liberated the eastern and northern provinces. The western provinces
column5: where the situation was worst
column6: however
column7: had to wait until the surrender of German forces in the Netherlands was negotiated on the eve of 5 May 1945 (three days before the general capitulation of Germany)
column8: in the Hotel de Wereld in Wageningen. Previously the Swedish Red Cross had been allowed to provide relief efforts
column9: and Allied forces were allowed to airdrop food over the German-occupied territories in Operation Manna.During Operation Amherst allied troops advanced into the North Netherlands. To support the advance of the Canadian 2nd Corps
column10: French paratroopers were dropped in Fryslân and Drenthe; these were the first allied troops to reach Fryslân. The French successfully captured the crucial Stokersverlaat Bridge. The region was successfully liberated shortly after.

column2: nearly 800 men of the Georgian Legion
column3: serving in the German army as Osttruppen
column4: rebelled on 5 April 1945. Their rebellion was crushed by the German army after two weeks of battle. 565 Georgians
column5: 120 inhabitants of Texel
column6: and 800 Germans died. The 228 surviving Georgians were forcibly repatriated to the Soviet Union when the war ended.

column2: Dutch citizens began taking the law into their own hands
column3: as had been done in other liberated countries
column4: such as France. Collaborators and Dutch women who had had relationships with men of the German occupying force
column5: called "Moffenmeiden" were abused and humiliated in public
column6: usually by having their heads shaved and painted orange.

column1: By the end of the war
column3: 901 Dutch men and women had died of war-related causes. The Netherlands had the highest per capita death rate of all Nazi-occupied countries in Western Europe (2.36%). Over half (107
column4: 000) were Holocaust victims. There were also many thousands of non-Dutch Jews in the total
column5: who had fled to the Netherlands from other countries
column6: seeking safety
column7: the most famous being Anne Frank. Another 30
column8: 000 died in the Dutch East Indies
column9: either while fighting the Japanese or in camps as Japanese POWs. Dutch civilians were also held in these camps.

column2: some accused of collaborating with the Germans were lynched or otherwise punished without trial. Men who had fought with the Germans in the Wehrmacht or Waffen-SS were used to clear minefields and suffered losses accordingly. Others were sentenced by courts for treason. Some were proven to have been wrongly arrested and were cleared of charges
column3: sometimes after being held in custody for a long period of time.

column1: The Dutch government initially developed plans to annex a sizeable portion of Germany (Bakker-Schut Plan)
column2: either with or without its German population — which in the latter case would have to be "Dutchified" — doubling the land area of the Netherlands. This plan was dropped after an Allied refusal (although two small villages were added to the Netherlands in 1949 and returned in 1963). One successfully-implemented plan was Black Tulip
column3: the deportation of all holders of German passports from the Netherlands
column4: resulting in several thousand German deportations.

column1: The bank balances of Dutch Jews who were killed are still the subject of legal proceedings
column2: more than 70 years after the end of the war.

column1: The end of the war also meant the final loss of the Dutch East Indies. Following the surrender of the Japanese in the Dutch East Indies
column2: Indonesian nationalists fought a four-year war of independence against Dutch and initially British Commonwealth forces
column3: eventually leading to the Dutch recognition of the independence of Indonesia. Many Dutch and Indonesians emigrated or returned to the Netherlands at this time.

column1: World War II left many lasting effects on Dutch society. On 4 May the Dutch commemorate those who died during the war. Among the living
column2: there are many who still bear the emotional scars of the war
column3: both first and second generation. In 2000
column4: the government was still granting 24
column5: 000 people an annual compensatory payment (although this also includes victims from later wars
column6: such as the Korean War).

column2: the Dutch Red Cross offered its “deep apologies” for its failure to act to protect Jews
column3: Sinti and Roma
column4: and political prisoners during the war
column5: following the publication of a study that it had commissioned from the NIOD Institute for War
column6: Holocaust and Genocide Studies.
